name: geo
headline:
Package geo provides tools for working with geotemporal data, such as
filtering and grouping by geographic location.

ST_Contains.name: ST_Contains
ST_Contains.headline:
ST_Contains returns boolean indicating whether the defined region contains a
specified GIS geometry.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region to test. Specify record properties for the shape.

parameters.name: geometry
parameters.headline: geometry: GIS geometry to test. Can be either point or linestring geometry.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline:
units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.
  Default is the `geo.units` option.

ST_Contains.flux_type: (geometry: A, region: B, ?units: {distance: string}) => bool where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
ST_Contains = (region, geometry, units=units) =>
    stContains(region: region, geometry: geometry, units: units)

ST_DWithin.name: ST_DWithin
ST_DWithin.headline:
ST_DWithin tests if the specified region is within a defined distance from
the specified GIS geometry and returns `true` or `false`.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region to test. Specify record properties for the shape.

parameters.name: geometry
parameters.headline: geometry: GIS geometry to test. Can be either point or linestring geometry.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.headline:
distance: Maximum distance allowed between the region and geometry.
  Define distance units with the `geo.units` option.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline:
units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.
  Default is the `geo.units` option.

ST_DWithin.flux_type: (distance: A, geometry: B, region: C, ?units: {distance: string}) => bool where A: Comparable + Equatable, B: Record, C: Record

source_location.source:
ST_DWithin = (region, geometry, distance, units=units) =>
    stDistance(region: region, geometry: geometry, units: units) <= distance

ST_Distance.name: ST_Distance
ST_Distance.headline: ST_Distance returns the distance from a given region to a specified GIS geometry.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region to test. Specify record properties for the shape.

parameters.name: geometry
parameters.headline: geometry: GIS geometry to test. Can be either point or linestring geometry.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline:
units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.
  Default is the `geo.units` option.

ST_Distance.flux_type: (geometry: A, region: B, ?units: {distance: string}) => float where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
ST_Distance = (region, geometry, units=units) =>
    stDistance(region: region, geometry: geometry, units: units)

ST_Intersects.name: ST_Intersects
ST_Intersects.headline:
ST_Intersects tests if the specified GIS geometry intersects with the
specified region and returns `true` or `false`.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region to test. Specify record properties for the shape.

parameters.name: geometry
parameters.headline: geometry: GIS geometry to test. Can be either point or linestring geometry.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline:
units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.
  Default is the `geo.units` option.

ST_Intersects.flux_type: (geometry: A, region: B, ?units: {distance: string}) => bool where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
ST_Intersects = (region, geometry, units=units) =>
    stDistance(region: region, geometry: geometry, units: units) <= 0.0

ST_Length.name: ST_Length
ST_Length.headline:
ST_Length returns the [spherical length or distance](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/SphericalDistance.html)
of the specified GIS geometry.

parameters.name: geometry
parameters.headline:
geometry: GIS geometry to test. Can be either point or linestring geometry.
  Point geometry will always return `0.0`.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline: units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.

ST_Length.flux_type: (geometry: A, ?units: {distance: string}) => float where A: Record

source_location.source: ST_Length = (geometry, units=units) => stLength(geometry: geometry, units: units)

ST_LineString.name: ST_LineString
ST_LineString.headline: ST_LineString converts a series of geographic points into linestring.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

ST_LineString.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{A with lon: C, lat: B}]) => stream[D] where D: Record

source_location.source:
ST_LineString = (tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> reduce(
            fn: (r, accumulator) =>
                ({
                    __linestring:
                        accumulator.__linestring + (if accumulator.__count > 0 then ", " else "")
                            +
                            string(v: r.lon) + " " + string(v: r.lat),
                    __count: accumulator.__count + 1,
                }),
            identity: {__linestring: "", __count: 0},
        )
        |> drop(columns: ["__count"])
        |> rename(columns: {__linestring: "st_linestring"})

asTracks.name: asTracks
asTracks.headline: asTracks groups rows into tracks (sequential, related data points).

parameters.name: groupBy
parameters.headline:
groupBy: Columns to group by. These columns should uniquely identify each track.
  Default is `["id","tid"]`.

parameters.name: orderBy
parameters.headline: orderBy: Columns to order results by. Default is `["_time"]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

source_location.source:
asTracks = (tables=<-, groupBy=["id", "tid"], orderBy=["_time"]) =>
    tables
        |> group(columns: groupBy)
        |> sort(columns: orderBy)

filterRows.name: filterRows
filterRows.headline: filterRows filters data by a specified geographic region with the option of strict filtering.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region containing the desired data points.

parameters.name: minSize
parameters.headline:
minSize: Minimum number of cells that cover the specified region.
  Default is `24`.

parameters.name: maxSize
parameters.headline:
maxSize: Maximum number of cells that cover the specified region.
  Default is `-1` (unlimited).

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline:
level: [S2 cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  of grid cells. Default is `-1`.

parameters.name: s2cellIDLevel
parameters.headline:
s2cellIDLevel: [S2 cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  used in the `s2_cell_id` tag. Default is `-1` (detects S2 cell level from the `s2_cell_id` tag).

parameters.name: strict
parameters.headline: strict: Enable strict geographic data filtering. Default is `true`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

filterRows.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[{B with s2_cell_id: string, lon: D, lat: C}],
    region: A,
    ?level: int,
    ?maxSize: int,
    ?minSize: int,
    ?s2cellIDLevel: int,
    ?strict: bool,
) => stream[{B with s2_cell_id: string, lon: D, lat: C}] where A: Record

source_location.source:
filterRows = (
        tables=<-,
        region,
        minSize=24,
        maxSize=-1,
        level=-1,
        s2cellIDLevel=-1,
        strict=true,
    ) =>
    {
        _columns =
            tables
                |> columns(column: "columns")
                |> findColumn(column: "columns", fn: (key) => true)
        _rows =
            if contains(value: "lat", set: _columns) then
                tables
                    |> gridFilter(
                        region: region,
                        minSize: minSize,
                        maxSize: maxSize,
                        level: level,
                        s2cellIDLevel: s2cellIDLevel,
                    )
            else
                tables
                    |> gridFilter(
                        region: region,
                        minSize: minSize,
                        maxSize: maxSize,
                        level: level,
                        s2cellIDLevel: s2cellIDLevel,
                    )
                    |> toRows()
        _result =
            if strict then
                _rows
                    |> strictFilter(region)
            else
                _rows

        return _result
    }

getGrid.name: getGrid
getGrid.headline: getGrid calculates a grid or set of cell ID tokens for a specified region.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline:
region: Region used to return S2 cell ID tokens.
  Specify record properties for the region shape.

parameters.name: minSize
parameters.headline: minSize: Minimum number of cells that cover the specified region.

parameters.name: maxSize
parameters.headline: maxSize: Minimum number of cells that cover the specified region.

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline: level: S2 cell level of grid cells.

parameters.name: maxLevel
parameters.headline: maxLevel: Maximumn S2 cell level of grid cells.

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline: units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.

getGrid.flux_type:
(
    region: A,
    units: {distance: string},
    ?level: int,
    ?maxLevel: int,
    ?maxSize: int,
    ?minSize: int,
) => {set: [string], level: int} where A: Record

source_location.source:
builtin getGrid : (
        region: T,
        ?minSize: int,
        ?maxSize: int,
        ?level: int,
        ?maxLevel: int,
        units: {distance: string},
    ) => {level: int, set: [string]}
    where
    T: Record

getLevel.name: getLevel
getLevel.headline: getLevel returns the S2 cell level of specified cell ID token.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline: token: S2 cell ID token.

source_location.source: builtin getLevel : (token: string) => int

gridFilter.name: gridFilter
gridFilter.headline: gridFilter filters data by a specified geographic region.

parameters.name: region
parameters.headline: region: Region containing the desired data points.

parameters.name: minSize
parameters.headline:
minSize: Minimum number of cells that cover the specified region.
  Default is `24`.

parameters.name: maxSize
parameters.headline:
maxSize: Maximum number of cells that cover the specified region.
  Default is `-1` (unlimited).

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline:
level: [S2 cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  of grid cells. Default is `-1`.

parameters.name: s2cellIDLevel
parameters.headline:
s2cellIDLevel: [S2 cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  used in the `s2_cell_id` tag. Default is `-1` (detects S2 cell level from the S2 cell ID token).

parameters.name: units
parameters.headline:
units: Record that defines the unit of measurement for distance.
  Default is the `geo.units` option.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

gridFilter.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[{B with s2_cell_id: string}],
    region: A,
    ?level: int,
    ?maxSize: int,
    ?minSize: int,
    ?s2cellIDLevel: int,
    ?units: {distance: string},
) => stream[{B with s2_cell_id: string}] where A: Record

source_location.source:
gridFilter = (
        tables=<-,
        region,
        minSize=24,
        maxSize=-1,
        level=-1,
        s2cellIDLevel=-1,
        units=units,
    ) =>
    {
        _s2cellIDLevel =
            if s2cellIDLevel == -1 then
                tables
                    |> _detectLevel()
            else
                s2cellIDLevel
        _grid =
            getGrid(
                region: region,
                minSize: minSize,
                maxSize: maxSize,
                level: level,
                maxLevel: _s2cellIDLevel,
                units: units,
            )

        return
            tables
                |> filter(
                    fn: (r) =>
                        if _grid.level == _s2cellIDLevel then
                            contains(value: r.s2_cell_id, set: _grid.set)
                        else
                            contains(
                                value: s2CellIDToken(token: r.s2_cell_id, level: _grid.level),
                                set: _grid.set,
                            ),
                )
    }

groupByArea.name: groupByArea
groupByArea.headline: groupByArea groups rows by geographic area.

parameters.name: newColumn
parameters.headline: newColumn: Name of the new column for the unique identifier for each geographic area.

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline:
level: [S2 Cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  used to determine the size of each geographic area.

parameters.name: s2cellIDLevel
parameters.headline:
s2cellIDLevel: [S2 Cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  used in the `s2_cell_id` tag. Default is `-1` (detects S2 cell level from the `s2_cell_id` tag).

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

groupByArea.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[{A with s2_cell_id: string, lon: float, lat: float}],
    level: int,
    newColumn: string,
    ?s2cellIDLevel: int,
) => stream[B] where B: Record

source_location.source:
groupByArea = (tables=<-, newColumn, level, s2cellIDLevel=-1) => {
    _s2cellIDLevel =
        if s2cellIDLevel == -1 then
            tables
                |> _detectLevel()
        else
            s2cellIDLevel
    _prepared =
        if level == _s2cellIDLevel then
            tables
                |> duplicate(column: "s2_cell_id", as: newColumn)
        else
            tables
                |> map(
                    fn: (r) =>
                        ({r with _s2_cell_id_xxx:
                                s2CellIDToken(point: {lat: r.lat, lon: r.lon}, level: level),
                        }),
                )
                |> rename(columns: {_s2_cell_id_xxx: newColumn})

    return
        _prepared
            |> group(columns: [newColumn])
}

s2CellIDToken.name: s2CellIDToken
s2CellIDToken.headline:
s2CellIDToken returns and S2 cell ID token for given cell or point at a
specified S2 cell level.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline: token: S2 cell ID token to update.

parameters.name: point
parameters.headline:
point: Record with `lat` and `lon` properties that specify the latitude and
  longitude in decimal degrees (WGS 84) of a point.

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline: level: S2 cell level to use when generating the S2 cell ID token.

s2CellIDToken.flux_type: (level: int, ?point: {lon: float, lat: float}, ?token: string) => string

source_location.source: builtin s2CellIDToken : (?token: string, ?point: {lat: float, lon: float}, level: int) => string

s2CellLatLon.name: s2CellLatLon
s2CellLatLon.headline: s2CellLatLon returns the latitude and longitude of the center of an S2 cell.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline: token: S2 cell ID token.

source_location.source: builtin s2CellLatLon : (token: string) => {lat: float, lon: float}

shapeData.name: shapeData
shapeData.headline:
shapeData renames existing latitude and longitude fields to **lat** and **lon**
and adds an **s2\_cell\_id** tag.

parameters.name: latField
parameters.headline: latField: Name of the existing field that contains the latitude value in decimal degrees (WGS 84).

parameters.name: lonField
parameters.headline: lonField: Name of the existing field that contains the longitude value in decimal degrees (WGS 84).

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline:
level: [S2 cell level](https://s2geometry.io/resources/s2cell_statistics.html)
  to use when generating the S2 cell ID token.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

shapeData.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[{C with _field: string}],
    latField: A,
    level: int,
    lonField: B,
) => stream[{D with s2_cell_id: string, lon: float, lat: float}] where A: Equatable, B: Equatable

source_location.source:
shapeData = (tables=<-, latField, lonField, level) =>
    tables
        |> map(
            fn: (r) =>
                ({r with _field:
                        if r._field == latField then
                            "lat"
                        else if r._field == lonField then
                            "lon"
                        else
                            r._field,
                }),
        )
        |> toRows()
        |> map(
            fn: (r) =>
                ({r with s2_cell_id: s2CellIDToken(point: {lat: r.lat, lon: r.lon}, level: level)}),
        )
        |> experimental.group(columns: ["s2_cell_id"], mode: "extend")

sqlInterval.name: sqlInterval
sqlInterval.headline: sqlInterval converts a duration value to a SQL interval string.

parameters.name: d
parameters.headline: d: Duration value to convert to SQL interval string.

source_location.source:
sqlInterval = (d) => {
    _durationString = string(v: d)
    _pipeRegex = (v=<-, r, t) => regexp.replaceAllString(v: v, r: r, t: t)
    _intervalString =
        _pipeRegex(v: _durationString, r: /([^\d]+)/, t: " $1 ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / ns /, t: " nanoseconds ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / us /, t: " microseconds ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / ms /, t: " milliseconds ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / s /, t: " seconds ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / m /, t: " minutes ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / h /, t: " hours ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / d /, t: " days ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / w /, t: " weeks ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / mo /, t: " months ")
            |> _pipeRegex(r: / y /, t: " years ")

    return strings.trimSpace(v: _intervalString)
}

APQ.name: APQ
APQ.headline:
APQ computes availability, performance, quality (APQ) and overall equipment
effectiveness (OEE) in producing parts.

parameters.name: runningState
parameters.headline: runningState: State value that represents a running state.

parameters.name: plannedTime
parameters.headline: plannedTime: Total time that equipment is expected to produce parts.

parameters.name: idealCycleTime

parameters.name: tables

APQ.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[D],
    idealCycleTime: A,
    plannedTime: B,
    runningState: C,
) => stream[{
    E with
    runTime: G,
    quality: float,
    performance: float,
    oee: float,
    availability: float,
    _time: F,
    _stop: F,
}] where C: Equatable, D: Record

source_location.source:
APQ = (tables=<-, runningState, plannedTime, idealCycleTime) =>
    computeAPQ(
        productionEvents: tables,
        partEvents: tables,
        runningState: runningState,
        plannedTime: plannedTime,
        idealCycleTime: idealCycleTime,
    )

computeAPQ.name: computeAPQ
computeAPQ.headline:
computeAPQ computes availability, performance, and quality (APQ)
and overall equipment effectiveness (OEE) using two separate input streams:
**production events** and **part events**.

parameters.name: productionEvents
parameters.headline:
productionEvents: Production events stream that contains the production
  state or start and stop events.

parameters.name: partEvents
parameters.headline:
partEvents: Part events that contains the running totals of parts produced and
    parts that do not meet quality standards.

parameters.name: runningState
parameters.headline: runningState: State value that represents a running state.

parameters.name: plannedTime
parameters.headline: plannedTime: Total time that equipment is expected to produce parts.

parameters.name: idealCycleTime
parameters.headline: idealCycleTime: Ideal minimum time to produce one part.

computeAPQ.flux_type:
(
    idealCycleTime: A,
    partEvents: stream[B],
    plannedTime: C,
    productionEvents: stream[D],
    runningState: E,
) => stream[{
    F with
    runTime: H,
    quality: float,
    performance: float,
    oee: float,
    availability: float,
    _time: G,
    _stop: G,
}] where B: Record, D: Record, E: Equatable

source_location.source:
computeAPQ = (
        productionEvents,
        partEvents,
        runningState,
        plannedTime,
        idealCycleTime,
    ) =>
    {
        availability =
            productionEvents
                |> events.duration(unit: 1ns, columnName: "runTime")
                |> filter(fn: (r) => r.state == runningState)
                |> sum(column: "runTime")
                |> map(
                    fn: (r) =>
                        ({r with _time: r._stop,
                            availability: float(v: r.runTime) / float(v: int(v: plannedTime)),
                        }),
                )
        totalCount =
            partEvents
                |> difference(columns: ["partCount"], nonNegative: true)
                |> sum(column: "partCount")
                |> duplicate(column: "_stop", as: "_time")
        badCount =
            partEvents
                |> difference(columns: ["badCount"], nonNegative: true)
                |> sum(column: "badCount")
                |> duplicate(column: "_stop", as: "_time")
        performance =
            experimental.join(
                left: availability,
                right: totalCount,
                fn: (left, right) =>
                    ({left with performance:
                            float(v: right.partCount) * float(v: int(v: idealCycleTime)) / float(
                                    v: left.runTime,
                                ),
                    }),
            )
        quality =
            experimental.join(
                left: badCount,
                right: totalCount,
                fn: (left, right) =>
                    ({left with quality:
                            (float(v: right.partCount) - float(v: left.badCount)) / float(
                                    v: right.partCount,
                                ),
                    }),
            )

        return
            experimental.join(
                left: performance,
                right: quality,
                fn: (left, right) =>
                    ({left with quality: right.quality,
                        oee: left.availability * left.performance * right.quality,
                    }),
            )
    }

name: prometheus
headline:
Package prometheus provides tools for working with
[Prometheus-formatted metrics](https://prometheus.io/docs/instrumenting/exposition_formats/).

histogramQuantile.name: histogramQuantile
histogramQuantile.headline: histogramQuantile calculates a quantile on a set of Prometheus histogram values.

parameters.name: quantile
parameters.headline: quantile: Quantile to compute. Must be a float value between 0.0 and 1.0.

parameters.name: metricVersion
parameters.headline:
metricVersion: [Prometheus metric parsing format](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/latest/reference/prometheus-metrics/)
  used to parse queried Prometheus data.
  Available versions are `1` and `2`.
  Default is `2`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

parameters.name: onNonmonotonic
parameters.headline:
onNonmonotonic: Describes behavior when counts are not monotonically increasing
  when sorted by upper bound. Default is `error`.

histogramQuantile.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{B with le: D, _field: C}], quantile: float, ?metricVersion: A, ?onNonmonotonic: string) => stream[E] where A: Equatable, C: Equatable, E: Record

source_location.source:
histogramQuantile = (tables=<-, quantile, metricVersion=2, onNonmonotonic="error") => {
    _version2 = (onNonmonotonic) =>
        tables
            |> group(mode: "except", columns: ["le", "_value"])
            |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with le: float(v: r.le)}))
            |> universe.histogramQuantile(quantile: quantile, onNonmonotonic: onNonmonotonic)
            |> group(mode: "except", columns: ["le", "_value", "_time"])
            |> set(key: "quantile", value: string(v: quantile))
            |> experimental.group(columns: ["quantile"], mode: "extend")

    _version1 = (onNonmonotonic) =>
        tables
            |> filter(fn: (r) => r._field != "sum" and r._field != "count")
            |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with le: float(v: r._field)}))
            |> group(mode: "except", columns: ["_field", "le", "_value"])
            |> universe.histogramQuantile(quantile: quantile, onNonmonotonic: onNonmonotonic)
            |> group(mode: "except", columns: ["le", "_value", "_time"])
            |> set(key: "quantile", value: string(v: quantile))
            |> experimental.group(columns: ["quantile"], mode: "extend")

    output =
        if metricVersion == 2 then
            _version2(onNonmonotonic)
        else if metricVersion == 1 then
            _version1(onNonmonotonic)
        else
            universe.die(msg: "Invalid metricVersion. Available versions are 1 and 2.")

    return output
}

parameters.headline: start: Earliest time to include in results.

parameters.name: stop
parameters.headline: stop: Latest time to include in results. Default is `now()`.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.headline: fields: Fields to filter by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: predicate
parameters.headline:
predicate: Predicate function that evaluates column values and returns `true` or `false`.
  Default is `(r) => true`.

inBucket.flux_type:
(
    bucket: string,
    measurement: A,
    start: B,
    ?fields: [string],
    ?predicate: (
        r: {
            C with
            _value: D,
            _time: time,
            _stop: time,
            _start: time,
            _measurement: string,
            _field: string,
        },
    ) => bool,
    ?stop: E,
) => stream[{
    C with
    _value: D,
    _time: time,
    _stop: time,
    _start: time,
    _measurement: string,
    _field: string,
}] where A: Equatable

source_location.source:
inBucket = (
    bucket,
    measurement,
    start,
    stop=now(),
    fields=[],
    predicate=(r) => true,
) =>
    fromRange(bucket: bucket, start: start, stop: stop)
        |> filterMeasurement(measurement)
        |> filter(fn: predicate)
        |> filterFields(fields)

name: usage
headline:
Package usage provides tools for collecting usage and usage limit data from
**InfluxDB Cloud**.

from.name: from
from.headline: from returns usage data from an **InfluxDB Cloud** organization.

parameters.name: start
parameters.headline: start: Earliest time to include in results.

parameters.name: stop
parameters.headline: stop: Latest time to include in results.

parameters.name: host
parameters.headline:
host: [InfluxDB Cloud region URL](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/cloud/reference/regions/).
  Default is `""`.

parameters.name: orgID
parameters.headline: orgID: InfluxDB Cloud organization ID. Default is `""`.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline:
token: InfluxDB Cloud [API token](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/cloud/security/tokens/).
  Default is `""`.

parameters.name: raw
parameters.headline:
raw: Return raw, high resolution usage data instead of downsampled usage data.
  Default is `false`.

from.flux_type:
(
    start: A,
    stop: B,
    ?host: string,
    ?orgID: string,
    ?raw: C,
    ?token: string,
) => stream[D] where D: Record

source_location.source:
from = (
        start,
        stop,
        host="",
        orgID="",
        token="",
        raw=false,
    ) =>
    {
        id = if orgID == "" then "{orgID}" else http.pathEscape(inputString: orgID)
        response =
            influxdb.api(
                method: "get",
                path: "/api/v2/orgs/" + id + "/usage",
                host: host,
                token: token,
                query: ["start": string(v: start), "stop": string(v: stop), "raw": string(v: raw)],
            )

        return
            if response.statusCode > 299 then
                die(
                    msg:
                        "organization usage request returned status " + string(
                                v: response.statusCode,
                            ) + ": " + string(v: response.body),
                )
            else
                csv.from(csv: string(v: response.body))
    }

limits.name: limits
limits.headline: limits returns a record containing usage limits for an **InfluxDB Cloud** organization.

parameters.name: host
parameters.headline:
host: [InfluxDB Cloud region URL](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/cloud/reference/regions/).
  Default is `""`.

parameters.name: orgID
parameters.headline: orgID: InfluxDB Cloud organization ID. Default is `""`.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline:
token: InfluxDB Cloud [API token](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/cloud/security/tokens/).
  Default is `""`.

source_location.source:
limits = (host="", orgID="", token="") => {
    id = if orgID == "" then "{orgID}" else http.pathEscape(inputString: orgID)
    response =
        influxdb.api(
            method: "get",
            path: "/api/v2/orgs/" + id + "/limits",
            host: host,
            token: token,
        )

    return
        if response.statusCode > 299 then
            die(
                msg:
                    "organization limits request returned status " + string(v: response.statusCode)
                        +
                        ": " + string(v: response.body),
            )
        else
            json.parse(data: response.body).limits
}

name: monitor
headline: Package monitor provides tools for monitoring and alerting with InfluxDB.

bucket.name: bucket
bucket.headline: bucket is the default bucket to store InfluxDB monitoring data in.

source_location.source: bucket = "_monitoring"

check.name: check
check.headline:
check checks input data and assigns a level (`ok`, `info`, `warn`, or `crit`)
to each row based on predicate functions.

parameters.name: crit
parameters.headline: crit: Predicate function that determines `crit` status. Default is `(r) => false`.

parameters.name: warn
parameters.headline: warn: Predicate function that determines `warn` status. Default is `(r) => false`.

parameters.name: info
parameters.headline: info: Predicate function that determines `info` status. Default is `(r) => false`.

parameters.name: ok
parameters.headline: ok: Predicate function that determines `ok` status. `Default is (r) => true`.

parameters.name: messageFn
parameters.headline: messageFn: Predicate function that constructs a message to append to each row.

parameters.name: data
parameters.headline: data: Check data to append to output used to identify this check.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

check.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[J],
    data: {A with tags: E, _type: D, _check_name: C, _check_id: B},
    messageFn: (
        r: {
            F with
            _type: D,
            _time: H,
            _time: time,
            _source_timestamp: int,
            _source_measurement: G,
            _measurement: G,
            _measurement: string,
            _level: string,
            _check_name: C,
            _check_id: B,
        },
    ) => I,
    ?crit: (r: {F with _time: H, _measurement: G}) => bool,
    ?info: (r: {F with _time: H, _measurement: G}) => bool,
    ?ok: (r: {F with _time: H, _measurement: G}) => bool,
    ?warn: (r: {F with _time: H, _measurement: G}) => bool,
) => stream[{
    F with
    _type: D,
    _time: H,
    _time: time,
    _source_timestamp: int,
    _source_measurement: G,
    _message: I,
    _measurement: G,
    _measurement: string,
    _level: string,
    _check_name: C,
    _check_id: B,
}] where E: Record, J: Record

source_location.source:
check = (
    tables=<-,
    data,
    messageFn,
    crit=(r) => false,
    warn=(r) => false,
    info=(r) => false,
    ok=(r) => true,
) =>
    tables
        |> experimental.set(o: data.tags)
        |> experimental.group(mode: "extend", columns: experimental.objectKeys(o: data.tags))
        |> map(
            fn: (r) =>
                ({r with
                    _measurement: "statuses",
                    _source_measurement: r._measurement,
                    _type: data._type,
                    _check_id: data._check_id,
                    _check_name: data._check_name,
                    _level:
                        if crit(r: r) then
                            levelCrit
                        else if warn(r: r) then
                            levelWarn
                        else if info(r: r) then
                            levelInfo
                        else if ok(r: r) then
                            levelOK
                        else
                            levelUnknown,
                    _source_timestamp: int(v: r._time),
                    _time: now(),
                }),
        )
        |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with _message: messageFn(r: r)}))
        |> experimental.group(
            mode: "extend",
            columns: [
                "_source_measurement",
                "_type",
                "_check_id",
                "_check_name",
                "_level",
            ],
        )
        |> write()

deadman.name: deadman
deadman.headline:
deadman detects when a group stops reporting data.
It takes a stream of tables and reports if groups have been observed since time `t`.

parameters.name: t
parameters.headline: t: Time threshold for the deadman check.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

deadman.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{B with _time: C}], t: A) => stream[{B with dead: bool, _time: C}] where A: Comparable, C: Comparable

source_location.source:
deadman = (t, tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> max(column: "_time")
        |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with dead: r._time < t}))

from.name: from
from.headline:
from retrieves check statuses stored in the `statuses` measurement in the
`_monitoring` bucket.

parameters.name: start
parameters.headline: start: Earliest time to include in results.

parameters.name: stop
parameters.headline: stop: Latest time to include in results. Default is `now()`.

parameters.name: fn
parameters.headline: fn: Predicate function that evaluates true or false.

from.flux_type:
(
    start: A,
    ?fn: (
        r: {
            B with
            _value: C,
            _time: time,
            _stop: time,
            _start: time,
            _measurement: string,
            _field: string,
        },
    ) => bool,
    ?stop: D,
) => stream[E] where E: Record

source_location.source:
from = (start, stop=now(), fn=(r) => true) =>
    influxdb.from(bucket: bucket)
        |> range(start: start, stop: stop)
        |> filter(fn: (r) => r._measurement == "statuses")
        |> filter(fn: fn)
        |> v1.fieldsAsCols()

logs.name: logs
logs.headline:
logs retrieves notification events stored in the `notifications` measurement
in the `_monitoring` bucket.

parameters.name: start
parameters.headline: start: Earliest time to include in results.

parameters.name: stop
parameters.headline: stop: Latest time to include in results. Default is `now()`.

parameters.name: fn
parameters.headline: fn: Predicate function that evaluates true or false.

source_location.source:
logs = (start, stop=now(), fn) =>
    influxdb.from(bucket: bucket)
        |> range(start: start, stop: stop)
        |> filter(fn: (r) => r._measurement == "notifications")
        |> filter(fn: fn)
        |> v1.fieldsAsCols()

notify.name: notify
notify.headline:
notify sends a notification to an endpoint and logs it in the `notifications`
measurement in the `_monitoring` bucket.

parameters.name: endpoint
parameters.headline: endpoint: A function that constructs and sends the notification to an endpoint.

parameters.name: data
parameters.headline: data: Notification data to append to the output.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

notify.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[E],
    data: A,
    endpoint: (<-: stream[{B with _time: C, _time: time, _status_timestamp: int, _measurement: string}]) => stream[D],
) => stream[D] where A: Record, D: Record, E: Record

source_location.source:
notify = (tables=<-, endpoint, data) =>
    tables
        |> experimental.set(o: data)
        |> experimental.group(mode: "extend", columns: experimental.objectKeys(o: data))
        |> map(
            fn: (r) =>
                ({r with _measurement: "notifications",
                    _status_timestamp: int(v: r._time),
                    _time: now(),
                }),
        )
        |> endpoint()
        |> experimental.group(mode: "extend", columns: ["_sent"])
        |> log()

stateChanges.name: stateChanges
stateChanges.headline:
stateChanges detects state changes in a stream of data with a `_level` column
and outputs records that change from `fromLevel` to `toLevel`.

parameters.name: fromLevel
parameters.headline: fromLevel: Level to detect a change from. Default is `"any"`.

parameters.name: toLevel
parameters.headline: toLevel: Level to detect a change to. Default is `"any"`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

stateChanges.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{C with _level: D}], ?fromLevel: A, ?toLevel: B) => stream[E] where A: Equatable, B: Equatable, D: Equatable, E: Record

source_location.source:
stateChanges = (fromLevel="any", toLevel="any", tables=<-) => {
    return
        if fromLevel == "any" and toLevel == "any" then
            tables |> stateChangesOnly()
        else
            tables |> _stateChanges(fromLevel: fromLevel, toLevel: toLevel)
}

stateChangesOnly.name: stateChangesOnly
stateChangesOnly.headline:
stateChangesOnly takes a stream of tables that contains a _level column
and returns a stream of tables grouped by `_level` where each record
represents a state change.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

stateChangesOnly.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{A with _level: B}]) => stream[C] where B: Equatable, C: Record

source_location.source:
stateChangesOnly = (tables=<-) => {
    return
        tables
            |> map(
                fn: (r) =>
                    ({r with level_value:
                            if r._level == levelCrit then
                                4
                            else if r._level == levelWarn then
                                3
                            else if r._level == levelInfo then
                                2
                            else if r._level == levelOK then
                                1
                            else
                                0,
                    }),
            )
            |> duplicate(column: "_level", as: "____temp_level____")
            |> drop(columns: ["_level"])
            |> rename(columns: {"____temp_level____": "_level"})
            |> sort(columns: ["_source_timestamp", "_time"], desc: false)
            |> difference(columns: ["level_value"])
            |> filter(fn: (r) => r.level_value != 0)
            |> drop(columns: ["level_value"])
            |> experimental.group(mode: "extend", columns: ["_level"])
}

source_location.source: option write = (tables=<-) => tables |> experimental.to(bucket: bucket)

quantile.name: quantile
quantile.headline:
quantile accounts checks for quantile values that are out of range, above 1.0 or
below 0.0, by either returning positive infinity or negative infinity in the `_value`
column respectively. `q` must be a float.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

parameters.name: q
parameters.headline: q: Quantile to compute (`[0.0 - 1.0]`).

parameters.name: method
parameters.headline: method: Quantile method to use.

quantile.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], q: float, ?method: string) => stream[A] where A: Record

source_location.source:
quantile = (q, tables=<-, method="exact_mean") =>
    // value is in normal range. We can use the normal quantile function
    if q <= 1.0 and q >= 0.0 then
        tables
            |> universe.quantile(q: q, method: method)
    else if q < 0.0 then
        tables
            |> reduce(identity: {_value: math.mInf(sign: -1)}, fn: (r, accumulator) => accumulator)
    else
        tables
            |> reduce(identity: {_value: math.mInf(sign: 1)}, fn: (r, accumulator) => accumulator)

name: testing
headline: Package testing provides functions for testing Flux operations.

assertMatches.name: assertMatches
assertMatches.headline: assertMatches tests whether a string matches a given regex.

parameters.name: got
parameters.headline: got: Value to test.

parameters.name: want
parameters.headline: want: Regex to test against.

assertMatches.flux_type: (got: string, want: regexp) => stream[{v: string, _diff: string}]

source_location.source:
assertMatches = (got, want) => {
    return
        if got =~ want then
            testing.assertEqualValues(got: "", want: "")
        else
            die(msg: "Regex `${regexp.getString(r: want)}` does not match `${got}`")
}

shouldErrorWithCode.name: shouldErrorWithCode
shouldErrorWithCode.headline: shouldErrorWithCode calls a function that catches any error and checks that the error matches the expected value.

parameters.name: fn
parameters.headline: fn: Function to call.

parameters.name: want
parameters.headline: want: Regular expression to match the expected error.

parameters.name: code
parameters.headline: code: Which flux error code to expect

shouldErrorWithCode.flux_type: (code: uint, fn: () => A, want: regexp) => stream[{match: bool, code: uint, _diff: string}]

source_location.source:
shouldErrorWithCode = (fn, want, code) => {
    got = experimental.catch(fn)

    return
        if exists got.msg then
            testing.diff(
                got: array.from(rows: [{code: got.code, match: got.msg =~ want}]),
                want: array.from(rows: [{code: code, match: true}]),
            )
        else
            die(msg: "shouldErrorWithCode expected an error")
}

name: pagerduty
headline: Package pagerduty provides functions for sending data to PagerDuty.

actionFromLevel.name: actionFromLevel
actionFromLevel.headline: actionFromLevel converts a monitoring level to a PagerDuty action.

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline: level: Monitoring level to convert to a PagerDuty action.

source_location.source: actionFromLevel = (level) => if strings.toLower(v: level) == "ok" then "resolve" else "trigger"

actionFromSeverity.name: actionFromSeverity
actionFromSeverity.headline: actionFromSeverity converts a severity to a PagerDuty action.

parameters.name: severity
parameters.headline: severity: Severity to convert to a PagerDuty action.

source_location.source:
actionFromSeverity = (severity) =>
    if strings.toLower(v: severity) == "ok" then
        "resolve"
    else
        "trigger"

dedupKey.name: dedupKey
dedupKey.headline:
dedupKey uses the group key of an input table to generate and store a
deduplication key in the `_pagerdutyDedupKey`column.
The function sorts, newline-concatenates, SHA256-hashes, and hex-encodes the
group key to create a unique deduplication key for each input table.

parameters.name: exclude
parameters.headline:
exclude: Group key columns to exclude when generating the deduplication key.
  Default is ["_start", "_stop", "_level"].

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

source_location.source:
builtin dedupKey : (
        <-tables: stream[A],
        ?exclude: [string],
    ) => stream[{A with _pagerdutyDedupKey: string}]

defaultURL.name: defaultURL
defaultURL.headline: defaultURL is the default PagerDuty URL used by functions in the `pagerduty` package.

source_location.source: option defaultURL = "https://events.pagerduty.com/v2/enqueue"

endpoint.name: endpoint
endpoint.headline: endpoint returns a function that sends a message to PagerDuty that includes output data.

parameters.name: url
parameters.headline: url: PagerDuty v2 Events API URL.

source_location.source:
endpoint = (url=defaultURL) =>
    (mapFn) =>
        (tables=<-) =>
            tables
                |> dedupKey()
                |> map(
                    fn: (r) => {
                        obj = mapFn(r: r)

                        response =
                            _sendEvent(
                                pagerdutyURL: url,
                                routingKey: obj.routingKey,
                                client: obj.client,
                                clientURL: obj.clientURL,
                                dedupKey: r._pagerdutyDedupKey,
                                class: obj.class,
                                group: obj.group,
                                severity: obj.severity,
                                eventAction: obj.eventAction,
                                source: obj.source,
                                component: record.get(r: obj, key: "component", default: ""),
                                summary: obj.summary,
                                timestamp: obj.timestamp,
                                customDetails:
                                    record.get(r: obj, key: "customDetails", default: record.any),
                            )

                        return {r with _sent: string(v: 2 == response.statusCode / 100),
                            _status: string(v: response.statusCode),
                            _body: string(v: response.body),
                        }
                    },
                )

sendEvent.name: sendEvent
sendEvent.headline: sendEvent sends an event to PagerDuty and returns the HTTP response code of the request.

parameters.name: pagerdutyURL
parameters.headline: pagerdutyURL: PagerDuty endpoint URL.

parameters.name: routingKey
parameters.headline: routingKey: Routing key generated from your PagerDuty integration.

parameters.name: client
parameters.headline: client: Name of the client sending the alert.

parameters.name: clientURL
parameters.headline: clientURL: URL of the client sending the alert.

parameters.name: dedupKey
parameters.headline:
dedupKey: Per-alert ID that acts as deduplication key and allows you to
  acknowledge or change the severity of previous messages.
  Supports a maximum of 255 characters.

parameters.name: class
parameters.headline: class: Class or type of the event.

parameters.name: group
parameters.headline: group: Logical grouping used by PagerDuty.

parameters.name: severity
parameters.headline: severity: Severity of the event.

parameters.name: eventAction
parameters.headline: eventAction: Event type to send to PagerDuty.

parameters.name: source
parameters.headline:
source: Unique location of the affected system.
  For example, the hostname or fully qualified domain name (FQDN).

parameters.name: component
parameters.headline: component: Component responsible for the event.

parameters.name: summary
parameters.headline:
summary: Brief text summary of the event used as the summaries or titles of associated alerts.
  The maximum permitted length is 1024 characters.

parameters.name: timestamp
parameters.headline: timestamp: Time the detected event occurred in RFC3339nano format.

parameters.name: customDetails
parameters.headline: customDetails: Record with additional details about the event.

sendEvent.flux_type:
(
    class: A,
    client: B,
    clientURL: C,
    dedupKey: D,
    eventAction: E,
    group: F,
    routingKey: G,
    severity: H,
    source: I,
    summary: string,
    timestamp: J,
    ?component: K,
    ?customDetails: L,
    ?pagerdutyURL: string,
) => int where L: Equatable

source_location.source:
sendEvent = (
    pagerdutyURL=defaultURL,
    routingKey,
    client,
    clientURL,
    dedupKey,
    class,
    group,
    severity,
    eventAction,
    source,
    component="",
    summary,
    timestamp,
    customDetails=record.any,
) =>
    _sendEvent(
        pagerdutyURL,
        routingKey,
        client,
        clientURL,
        dedupKey,
        class,
        group,
        severity,
        eventAction,
        source,
        component,
        summary,
        timestamp,
        customDetails,
    ).statusCode

severityFromLevel.name: severityFromLevel
severityFromLevel.headline: severityFromLevel converts an InfluxDB status level to a PagerDuty severity.

parameters.name: level
parameters.headline: level: InfluxDB status level to convert to a PagerDuty severity.

source_location.source:
severityFromLevel = (level) => {
    lvl = strings.toLower(v: level)
    sev =
        if lvl == "warn" then
            "warning"
        else if lvl == "crit" then
            "critical"
        else if lvl == "info" then
            "info"
        else if lvl == "ok" then
            "info"
        else
            "error"

    return sev
}

name: slack
headline: Package slack provides functions for sending messages to [Slack](https://slack.com/).

defaultURL.name: defaultURL
defaultURL.headline: defaultURL defines the default Slack API URL used by functions in the `slack` package.

source_location.source: option defaultURL = "https://slack.com/api/chat.postMessage"

endpoint.name: endpoint
endpoint.headline: endpoint returns a function that can be used to send a message to Slack per input row.

parameters.name: url
parameters.headline: url: Slack API URL. Default is  `https://slack.com/api/chat.postMessage`.

parameters.name: token
parameters.headline: token: Slack API token. Default is `""`.

source_location.source:
endpoint = (url=defaultURL, token="") =>
    (mapFn) =>
        (tables=<-) =>
            tables
                |> map(
                    fn: (r) => {
                        obj = mapFn(r: r)

                        return {r with _sent:
                                string(
                                    v:
                                        2 == message(
                                                url: url,
                                                token: token,
                                                channel: obj.channel,
                                                text: obj.text,
                                                color: obj.color,
                                            ) / 100,
                                ),
                        }
                    },
                )

message sends a single message to a Slack channel and returns the HTTP
response code of the request.

parameters.headline: channel: Slack channel or user to send the message to.

parameters.name: text
parameters.headline: text: Message text.

parameters.name: color

parameters.name: want
parameters.headline: want: Stream that contains data to test against.

parameters.headline: verbose: Include detailed differences in output. Default is `false`.

parameters.headline: nansEqual: Consider `NaN` float values equal. Default is `false`.

diff.flux_type:
(
    <-got: stream[A],
    want: stream[A],
    ?epsilon: B,
    ?nansEqual: C,
    ?verbose: D,
) => stream[{A with _diff: string}]

source_location.source:
diff = (
        got=<-,
        want,
        verbose=false,
        epsilon=0.000001,
        nansEqual=false,
    ) =>
    {
        return
            experimental.diff(got, want)
                |> yield(name: "errorOutput")
    }

load.headline: load loads test data from a stream of tables.

parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

source_location.source: option load = (tables=<-) => tables

shouldError.name: shouldError
shouldError.headline: shouldError calls a function that catches any error and checks that the error matches the expected value.

parameters.name: fn
parameters.headline: fn: Function to call.

parameters.name: want
parameters.headline: want: Regular expression to match the expected error.

source_location.source:
shouldError = (fn, want) => {
    got = experimental.catch(fn)

    return
        if exists got.msg then
            array.from(rows: [{v: got.msg}])
                |> filter(fn: (r) => r.v !~ want)
                |> yield(name: "errorOutput")
        else
            die(msg: "shouldError expected an error")
}

name: universe
headline:
Package universe provides options and primitive functions that are
loaded into the Flux runtime by default and do not require an
import statement.

aggregateWindow.name: aggregateWindow
aggregateWindow.headline:
aggregateWindow downsamples data by grouping data into fixed windows of time
and applying an aggregate or selector function to each window.

parameters.name: every
parameters.headline: every: Duration of time between windows.

parameters.name: period
parameters.headline: period: Duration of windows. Default is the `every` value.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.headline: offset: Duration to shift the window boundaries by. Default is `0s`.

parameters.name: fn
parameters.headline: fn: Aggregate or selector function to apply to each time window.

parameters.name: location
parameters.headline: location: Location used to determine timezone. Default is the `location` option.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to operate on.

parameters.name: timeSrc
parameters.headline:
timeSrc: Column to use as the source of the new time value for aggregate values.
  Default is `_stop`.

parameters.name: timeDst
parameters.headline:
timeDst: Column to store time values for aggregate values in.
  Default is `_time`.

parameters.name: createEmpty
parameters.headline: createEmpty: Create empty tables for empty window. Default is `true`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

aggregateWindow.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[D],
    every: duration,
    fn: (<-: stream[B], column: A) => stream[C],
    ?column: A,
    ?createEmpty: bool,
    ?location: {zone: string, offset: duration},
    ?offset: duration,
    ?period: duration,
    ?timeDst: string,
    ?timeSrc: string,
) => stream[E] where B: Record, C: Record, D: Record, E: Record

source_location.source:
aggregateWindow = (
    every,
    period=0s,
    fn,
    offset=0s,
    location=location,
    column="_value",
    timeSrc="_stop",
    timeDst="_time",
    createEmpty=true,
    tables=<-,
) =>
    tables
        |> window(
            every: every,
            period: period,
            offset: offset,
            location: location,
            createEmpty: createEmpty,
        )
        |> fn(column: column)
        |> _fillEmpty(createEmpty: createEmpty)
        |> duplicate(column: timeSrc, as: timeDst)
        |> window(every: inf, timeColumn: timeDst)

doubleEMA.name: doubleEMA
doubleEMA.headline:
doubleEMA returns the double exponential moving average (DEMA) of values in
the `_value` column grouped into `n` number of points, giving more weight to
recent data.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of points to average.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

doubleEMA.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{A with _value: B}], n: int) => stream[C] where B: Numeric, C: Record

source_location.source:
doubleEMA = (n, tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> exponentialMovingAverage(n: n)
        |> duplicate(column: "_value", as: "__ema")
        |> exponentialMovingAverage(n: n)
        |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with _value: 2.0 * r.__ema - r._value}))
        |> drop(columns: ["__ema"])

highestAverage.name: highestAverage
highestAverage.headline:
highestAverage calculates the average of each input table and returns the
highest `n` averages.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of records to return.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to evaluate. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: groupColumns
parameters.headline: groupColumns: List of columns to group by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

highestAverage.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], n: int, ?column: string, ?groupColumns: [string]) => stream[B] where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
highestAverage = (n, column="_value", groupColumns=[], tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> _highestOrLowest(
            n: n,
            column: column,
            groupColumns: groupColumns,
            reducer: (tables=<-) => tables |> mean(column: column),
            _sortLimit: top,
        )

highestMax.headline:
highestMax selects the record with the highest value in the specified `column`
from each input table and returns the highest `n` records.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of records to return.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to evaluate. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: groupColumns
parameters.headline: groupColumns: List of columns to group by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: tables

source_location.source:
highestMax =
    (n, column="_value", groupColumns=[], tables=<-) =>
        tables
            |> _highestOrLowest(
                n: n,
                column: column,
                groupColumns: groupColumns,
                // TODO(nathanielc): Once max/min support selecting based on multiple columns change this to pass all columns.
                reducer: (tables=<-) => tables |> max(column: column),
                _sortLimit: top,
            )

hourSelection = (

increase.name: increase
increase.headline: increase returns the cumulative sum of non-negative differences between subsequent values.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.headline: columns: List of columns to operate on. Default is `["_value"]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

increase.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], ?columns: [string]) => stream[B] where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
increase = (tables=<-, columns=["_value"]) =>
    tables
        |> difference(nonNegative: true, columns: columns, keepFirst: true, initialZero: true)
        |> cumulativeSum(columns: columns)

kaufmansER.name: kaufmansER
kaufmansER.headline:
kaufmansER computes the Kaufman's Efficiency Ratio (KER) of values in the
`_value` column for each input table.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Period or number of points to use in the calculation.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

kaufmansER.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], n: int) => stream[{B with _value: float, _value: float}] where A: Record

source_location.source:
kaufmansER = (n, tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> chandeMomentumOscillator(n: n)
        |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with _value: math.abs(x: r._value) / 100.0}))

lowestAverage.name: lowestAverage
lowestAverage.headline:
lowestAverage calculates the average of each input table and returns the lowest
`n` averages.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of records to return.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to evaluate. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: groupColumns
parameters.headline: groupColumns: List of columns to group by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

lowestAverage.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], n: int, ?column: string, ?groupColumns: [string]) => stream[B] where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
lowestAverage = (n, column="_value", groupColumns=[], tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> _highestOrLowest(
            n: n,
            column: column,
            groupColumns: groupColumns,
            reducer: (tables=<-) => tables |> mean(column: column),
            _sortLimit: bottom,
        )

lowestCurrent.name: lowestCurrent
lowestCurrent.headline:
lowestCurrent selects the last record from each input table and returns the
lowest `n` records.

parameters.name: n

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to evaluate. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: groupColumns
parameters.headline: groupColumns: List of columns to group by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

source_location.source:
lowestCurrent = (n, column="_value", groupColumns=[], tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> _highestOrLowest(
            n: n,
            column: column,
            groupColumns: groupColumns,
            reducer: (tables=<-) => tables |> last(column: column),
            _sortLimit: bottom,
        )

lowestMin.name: lowestMin
lowestMin.headline:
lowestMin selects the record with the lowest value in the specified `column`
from each input table and returns the bottom `n` records.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of records to return.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to evaluate. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: groupColumns
parameters.headline: groupColumns: List of columns to group by. Default is `[]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

lowestMin.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], n: int, ?column: string, ?groupColumns: [string]) => stream[A] where A: Record

source_location.source:
lowestMin =
    (n, column="_value", groupColumns=[], tables=<-) =>
        tables
            |> _highestOrLowest(
                n: n,
                column: column,
                groupColumns: groupColumns,
                // TODO(nathanielc): Once max/min support selecting based on multiple columns change this to pass all columns.
                reducer: (tables=<-) => tables |> min(column: column),
                _sortLimit: bottom,
            )

stateCount.headline: stateCount returns the number of consecutive rows in a given state.

timeWeightedAvg.name: timeWeightedAvg
timeWeightedAvg.headline:
timeWeightedAvg returns the time-weighted average of non-null values in
`_value` column as a float for each input table.

parameters.name: unit
parameters.headline: unit: Unit of time to use to compute the time-weighted average.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

timeWeightedAvg.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], unit: duration) => stream[{B with _value: float, _value: float, _stop: D, _start: C}] where A: Record

source_location.source:
timeWeightedAvg = (tables=<-, unit) =>
    tables
        |> integral(unit: unit, interpolate: "linear")
        |> map(
            fn: (r) =>
                ({r with _value:
                        r._value * float(v: uint(v: unit)) / float(
                                v: int(v: r._stop) - int(v: r._start),
                            ),
                }),
        )

timedMovingAverage.name: timedMovingAverage
timedMovingAverage.headline:
timedMovingAverage returns the mean of values in a defined time range at a
specified frequency.

parameters.name: every
parameters.headline: every: Frequency of time window.

parameters.name: period
parameters.headline: period: Length of each averaged time window.

parameters.name: column
parameters.headline: column: Column to operate on. Default is `_value`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

timedMovingAverage.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], every: duration, period: duration, ?column: string) => stream[B] where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
timedMovingAverage = (every, period, column="_value", tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> window(every: every, period: period)
        |> mean(column: column)
        |> duplicate(column: "_stop", as: "_time")
        |> window(every: inf)

top.name: top
top.headline:
top sorts each input table by specified columns and keeps the top `n` records
in each table.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of rows to return from each input table.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.headline: columns: List of columns to sort by. Default is `["_value"]`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

top.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[A], n: int, ?columns: [string]) => stream[A] where A: Record

source_location.source:
top = (n, columns=["_value"], tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> _sortLimit(n: n, columns: columns, desc: true)

tripleEMA.name: tripleEMA
tripleEMA.headline:
tripleEMA returns the triple exponential moving average (TEMA) of values in
the `_value` column.

parameters.name: n
parameters.headline: n: Number of points to use in the calculation.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

tripleEMA.flux_type: (<-tables: stream[{A with _value: B}], n: int) => stream[C] where B: Numeric, C: Record

source_location.source:
tripleEMA = (n, tables=<-) =>
    tables
        |> exponentialMovingAverage(n: n)
        |> duplicate(column: "_value", as: "__ema1")
        |> exponentialMovingAverage(n: n)
        |> duplicate(column: "_value", as: "__ema2")
        |> exponentialMovingAverage(n: n)
        |> map(fn: (r) => ({r with _value: 3.0 * r.__ema1 - 3.0 * r.__ema2 + r._value}))
        |> drop(columns: ["__ema1", "__ema2"])

window.name: window
window.headline: window groups records using regular time intervals.

parameters.name: every
parameters.headline: every: Duration of time between windows.

parameters.name: period
parameters.headline: period: Duration of windows. Default is the `every` value.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.headline: offset: Duration to shift the window boundaries by. Default is `0s`.

parameters.name: location
parameters.headline: location: Location used to determine timezone. Default is the `location` option.

parameters.name: timeColumn
parameters.headline: timeColumn: Column that contains time values. Default is `_time`.

parameters.name: startColumn
parameters.headline: startColumn: Column to store the window start time in. Default is `_start`.

parameters.name: stopColumn
parameters.headline: stopColumn: Column to store the window stop time in. Default is `_stop`.

parameters.name: createEmpty
parameters.headline: createEmpty: Create empty tables for empty window. Default is `false`.

parameters.name: tables
parameters.headline: tables: Input data. Default is piped-forward data (`<-`).

window.flux_type:
(
    <-tables: stream[A],
    ?createEmpty: bool,
    ?every: duration,
    ?location: {zone: string, offset: duration},
    ?offset: duration,
    ?period: duration,
    ?startColumn: string,
    ?stopColumn: string,
    ?timeColumn: string,
) => stream[B] where A: Record, B: Record

source_location.source:
window = (
    tables=<-,
    every=0s,
    period=0s,
    offset=0s,
    location=location,
    timeColumn="_time",
    startColumn="_start",
    stopColumn="_stop",
    createEmpty=false,
) =>
    tables
        |> _window(
            every,
            period,
            offset,
            location,
            timeColumn,
            startColumn,
            stopColumn,
            createEmpty,
        )
